title-group.article-title: Factors Affecting Subspecialty Referrals by Pediatric Primary Care Providers for Children With Obesity-Related Comorbidities

article-meta.aff: 2Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Elsie M. Taveras, Division of General Pediatrics, Department of Pediatrics, Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts General Hospital, 175 Cambridge Street, 5th Floor, CPZD 579B, Boston, MA 02214, USA. Email: etaveras@partners.org

abstract.p: Objective. To determine referral patterns from pediatric primary care to subspecialists for overweight/obesity and related comorbidities. Methods. We used the National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey and National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey to identify overweight/obesity and 5 related comorbidities in primary care visits between 2005 and 2009 by children 6 to 18 years. The primary outcome was whether the visit ended in referral. We used multivariable analysis to examine factors associated with referral. Results. We identified 34 225 database visits. A total of 17.1% were with overweight (body mass index = 85th to 94th percentile) or obese (body mass index ≥ 95th percentile) patients. A total of 7.1% of primary care visits with overweight/obese children ended in referral. Referral was more likely when obesity was the reason for visit (odds ratio = 2.83; 95% confidence interval = 1.61-4.97) but was not associated with presence of a comorbidity (odds ratio = 1.35; 95% confidence interval = 0.75-2.44). Conclusions. Most overweight or obese children are not referred, regardless of comorbidity status. One reason may be low levels of appropriate diagnosis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As the prevalence of pediatric overweight and obesity has increased to current levels of 31.8% and 16.9%, respectively, among children ages 2 to 19 years,1 pediatric primary care providers have increasingly been faced with diagnosing and managing obesity-related comorbidities. As in adults, increased body mass index (BMI) in children is associated with increased risk of dyslipidemia,2,3 hypertension,2,3 elevated glucose,3 elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) suggestive of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease,4 and depression.5 These conditions are encountered frequently in general pediatric practice, with prevalence estimates ranging from 7% for hypertension in overweight children to 27% for depression in obese adolescents.2-5 This growing group of patients with chronic conditions that used to be seen primarily in adults represents a relatively new population within pediatric primary care. As such, it is important to understand whether pediatric primary care providers are caring for these children within the primary care system or referring them to subspecialty care.

In recent years, national guidelines have been published to address assessment and management of obesity and its comorbidities.6-14 The guidelines recommend that identification and initial management of overweight and obesity occur in primary care, with referral to increasing levels of care based on BMI, age, and presence of comorbidities.6 Testing for comorbidities appropriate for the primary care setting includes blood pressure, lipids, transaminases, and glucose.7,8 Many guidelines state that, in less severe cases, initial management or retesting in primary care is appropriate.8-11 However, more severe cases, such as stage 2 hypertension or new diagnosis of diabetes, warrant immediate subspecialty referral, as do less severe cases in which initial lifestyle management is unsuccessful.

Prior work regarding subspecialty referral rates from primary care providers has shown that, at a single hospital-based academic primary care center, 5% of patients with identified obesity had documented referrals to endocrinology and 3% to preventive cardiology15; these numbers are lower than the 23% of surveyed providers at a different academic center who reported referring obese patients to an endocrinologist.16 Information regarding factors affecting the likelihood of referral to other physicians was not provided in either study; one study noted that older and heavier patients were more likely to be referred to a nutritionist.15

The goal of the current study was to determine referral patterns, including rate and factors that affect likelihood of referral, from pediatric primary care providers to subspecialists in children and adolescents with obesity and related comorbidities in a nationally representative sample. Based on previous published literature, we hypothesized that older patients, those with a higher BMI, and those with an identified comorbidity would be more likely to be referred from primary to subspecialty care.

sec.title: Data Sources
sec.p: We used data from the National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NAMCS) and National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NHAMCS). Both data sources are annual cross-sectional surveys conducted by the National Center for Health Statistics of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The purpose of the NAMCS and NHAMCS is to examine ambulatory care provision and utilization in the United States. They employ a multistage complex probability sampling design to produce a nationally representative sample of ambulatory care visits. These public-use data sets include design variables (weights) that can be used to construct national estimates. NAMCS is a sample of visits to nonfederal office-based providers. NHAMCS samples visits to nonfederal outpatient departments, ambulatory surgery centers, and hospital emergency departments. For the current study, we used pediatric data from the 2005-2009 NAMCS and NHAMCS.

sec.title: Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria and Variable Definitions
sec.p: Our sample for analysis included visits to an office or outpatient department by children 6 to 18 years of age; younger children were excluded given low rates of comorbidities among children age 5 and under. We excluded visits to hospital emergency departments.

For each visit, the patient was classified as overweight or obese if at least 1 of the following 3 criteria was met: (a) age and gender-specific BMI percentile greater than or equal to 85th percentile from CDC growth references17 calculated from documented weight and height; (b) International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision (ICD-9)18 diagnosis code for overweight and/or obesity used in any of the 3 diagnosis code fields (see the appendix for list of eligible codes); or (c) provider responded “Yes” to the survey question, “Regardless of the diagnosis . . . does the patient now have: obesity?” This definition was designed to maximize sensitivity and identify the greatest number of visits with overweight or obese children.

Visits were identified as primary care, specialty care, or unknown using responses to survey questions about primary care and referral status for the visit (see Figure 1). Primary care visits included those with the primary care provider and other providers in the same office who were substituting for the primary provider at a given visit. Based on these classifications, primary care visits were included and specialty visits and visits of unknown type were excluded from the analysis of referral status.

caption.p: Algorithm for identifying a visit as primary care, subspecialty care, or unknown.

sec.p: Variables recoded for the purpose of the analysis included primary source of payment and race/ethnicity. Primary source of payment was categorized as public (Medicare and Medicaid/CHIP), private, other (self-pay, no charge, worker’s compensation, other), and unknown. Race and ethnicity were combined into mutually exclusive categories for non-Hispanic White, non-Hispanic Black, Hispanic, and non-Hispanic Other. Due to high nonresponse on survey items regarding race and ethnicity, the public-use NAMCS and NHAMCS data sets provide imputed values that we used in this analysis. Detailed information regarding imputation methodology can be found in the micro-data file documentation for each survey year.19,20 Other imputed variables used in this analysis included child age and sex, both of which had an average nonresponse of less than 3% across all survey years included. The 5 years were divided into 2 “eras,” before (2005-2007) and after (2008-2009) publication of the national obesity guidelines.6 Region and metropolitan statistical area were included without recoding.

The reason for visit was classified as overweight or obesity if any of the 3 diagnosis field codes was one of the eligible ICD-9 codes for overweight or obesity, or if any of the 3 patient-generated reasons for visit codes was weight gain (1040.0) or diet and nutritional counseling (4600.0). Well-child visits and comorbidities (hypertension, hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia, elevated transaminases, and depression) were identified using inclusive strategies, with definitions designed to maximize sensitivity. A visit was defined as a well-child visit in the presence of appropriate patient-generated reason for visit codes or provider-generated ICD-9 codes (see the appendix). A patient was coded as having a given comorbidity in the presence of a patient-generated reason for visit related to a given symptom or diagnosis, an appropriate provider-generated ICD-9 diagnosis code, or a positive response of the provider to direct survey questions regarding the presence of hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and depression, regardless of reason for visit (see the appendix). Hypertension was also coded as present if documented systolic or diastolic blood pressure was greater than the 95th percentile for age, gender, and height from the Fourth Report on the Diagnosis, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure in Children and Adolescents.9

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: We used survey procedures in SAS 9.3 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC) to account for the complex sampling design surveys and to produce national weighted estimates from the representative sample using Taylor series linearization variance estimation. Chi-square tests were used to test for differences in proportions between visit disposition referral categories. Multivariable logistic regression analysis was used to examine factors associated with a visit ending in specialist referral. Key demographic variables and factors that were found to be significant predictors of referral status in bivariate analyses were included in the logistic regression model to examine the adjusted association with referral status.

Due to low numbers of sampled visits for each specific comorbidity leading to potentially unreliable national estimates, a dichotomous variable indicating the presence or absence of any of the comorbidities of interest was created for the purpose of bivariate and multivariable analysis. According to the NAMCS and NHAMCS documentation,19,20 estimates may be considered unreliable when the sampled number of visits is less than 30 or the relative standard error of the estimate is more than 30%, and these estimates should be interpreted with caution.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 17.1% (SE = 0.55) of all visits with 6 to 18 year olds were with children classified as overweight or obese. Information regarding patient demographics, visit type, and comorbidity prevalence in these overweight and obese patients is shown in Table 1. Patients with an “unknown” BMI met criteria for overweight or obesity based on the inclusive definition, but had either height or weight missing and therefore could not have BMI calculated and classified. Figure 2 contains a flow diagram of visits, showing how the 3114 visits with overweight or obese children in primary care, representing 61 290 145 national visits, were identified. A total of 7.1% of the primary care visits with these children ended in referral.

caption.p: Patient Characteristics in Ambulatory Visits With an Overweight or Obese Child Aged 6 to 18 Years (n = 6593; N = 88 420 745).

fn.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; MSA, metropolitan statistical area; NAFLD, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Unknown BMI refers to patients who met criteria for overweight or obesity based on inclusive definition but had missing height or weight.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Era refers to years before (2005-2007) and after (2008-2009) published recommendations for treatment of pediatric overweight and obesity.6

caption.p: Flowchart showing identification of visits with overweight and obese children in primary care.

sec.p: Table 2 shows the bivariate analysis of factors affecting visit disposition. Factors significantly associated (P < .05) with increased likelihood of referral out of primary care included female gender, BMI percentile category (with unknown BMI having the highest referral rate), region (with the Midwest having the highest referral rate and Northeast the lowest), obesity as reason for visit, presence of hyperglycemia, and presence of depression.

caption.p: Bivariate Analysis of Factors Affecting Visit Disposition in Primary Care Visits With Overweight and Obese Children Aged 6 to 18 Years (n = 3114; N = 61 290 145).

fn.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; MSA, metropolitan statistical area; NAFLD, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Unknown BMI refers to patients who met criteria for overweight or obesity based on inclusive definition but had missing height or weight.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Era refers to years before (2005-2007) and after (2008-2009) published recommendations for treatment of pediatric overweight and obesity.6

fn.label: c
fn.p: P value not reported due to low sample number.

sec.p: Table 3 shows the results of multivariable logistic regression including all predictors of visit disposition, with comorbidities combined into a single dichotomous indicator. In this model, the 2 factors significantly associated with likelihood of referral out of primary care were region (P = .0058), with those in the Midwest most likely to be referred and those in the Northeast least likely, and obesity as reason for visit (P = .0003), which increased likelihood of referral. In a simplified model including only those factors with P < .2 in the full multivariate model, the only 2 significant factors remained region and obesity as reason for visit.

caption.p: Multivariable Logistic Regression With Predictors of Visit Disposition in Primary Care Visits With Overweight and Obese Children Aged 6 to 18 Years (n = 3114; N = 61 290 145).

fn.p: Abbreviations: OR, odds ratio; CI, confidence interval; BMI, body mass index; MSA, metropolitan statistical area.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Unknown BMI refers to patients who met criteria for overweight or obesity based on inclusive definition but had missing height or weight.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Era refers to years before (2005-2007) and after (2008-2009) published recommendations for treatment of pediatric overweight and obesity.6

fn.label: c
fn.p: Hypertension, dyslipidemia, hyperglycemia, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, or depression.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this national study of 61 290 145 ambulatory primary care visits with children ages 6 to 18 years, we found that only 7.1% of primary care visits of overweight or obese children ended in referral to another provider for subspecialty care. In multivariable analysis, only region of the United States and obesity as the reason for the visit were associated with subspecialty referral. Contrary to our a priori hypothesis, the presence of a comorbid condition did not increase the odds of a visit ending with a referral.

While prior studies had examined referral rate for obese children in single academic centers,15,16 to our knowledge this is the first to address this question on a national scale. Our finding of 7.1% of visits ending in referral was similar to the prior findings that showed 5% of obese children in a single center had documented endocrinology referrals and 3% had documented preventive cardiology referrals.15 The referral rate was higher in the study that relied on self-report of typical practice, with 23% reporting endocrinology referrals and 17% reporting referrals to a specialized obesity clinic,16 suggesting that providers may overestimate their tendency to refer obese children and adolescents for specialty care.

There are 3 possible reasons why a provider may not refer a patient for specialty care: the provider may not correctly identify obesity or one of the comorbidities, may diagnose the patient correctly but decide to provide initial care in the primary care setting with plans to refer later, or may diagnose the patient correctly and decide to provide continuing care in the primary care setting without plans to refer. Given that the NAMCS and NHAMCS data are collected at the visit level in a cross-sectional manner, it is not possible to track individual patients over time, and there is no survey question about plans for future referrals. However, there are some indications that the rate is affected, at least in part, by lack of appropriate diagnosis.

The national prevalence of overweight is 31.8% and of obesity is 16.9% among children 2 to 19 years. After exclusion of the youngest children, who have lower rates of overweight and obesity and were excluded in our study due to low comorbidity rates, these numbers are higher: among 6 to 19 year olds, the prevalence of overweight is 33.2%, and of obesity is 18.2%.1 Because it is recommended that obese children, particularly those with comorbidities, have close medical follow-up, one would expect this population to be overrepresented in a sample based on visits rather than patients. Instead, the percentage of visits with overweight or obese children was just over half the national prevalence, suggesting that many overweight and obese children were not identified as such despite our use of an inclusive definition. This assertion is supported by our related analysis of obesity diagnosis in children 2 to 18 years, in which we found that only 15.4% of children who are obese based on documented height and weight are identified as such by ICD-9 code or positive response to direct questioning about the presence of obesity.21 Similarly, the rates of the included comorbidities were lower than previously shown2-5; the exception was hypertension, which by our criteria could be diagnosed based on mapping of documented blood pressure to standardized percentiles, and therefore did not rely solely on provider identification. These results support prior work showing that only 22% of obese children were screened for dyslipidemia, hyperglycemia, and abnormal liver function.22

It was unexpected that so few variables affected referral rate. We had hypothesized that obesity as reason for visit would be positively associated with referral rate, which it was. While we did not specify a hypothesis about region of the country, it was surprising that the 2 regions with relatively higher referral rates were the Midwest and the West, given that these contain the census divisions (West North Central and Mountain) with furthest distance to pediatric subspecialists.23 We were also surprised to find no association between referral status and the variables age, BMI percentile, and presence of comorbidities. Regarding comorbidities, the bivariate analysis suggested that referral rate was higher for certain comorbidities, including depression and hyperglycemia, but not for hypertension or dyslipidemia (abnormal liver function could not be assessed due to small sample size). It is possible that primary care providers are initiating lifestyle intervention for certain comorbidities in the office, while there are others they feel less comfortable caring for and tend to refer. Given the small sample sizes of identified comorbidities, the national estimates were not reliable for the individual comorbidities so they were combined for the multivariable analysis; it is therefore not possible to determine whether this finding is robust.

A strength of this study is that, while prior work has examined obesity-related complications in pediatrics,22 this is the first that we know of to do so using a nationally representative database, allowing the results to be generalizable. This work is also novel in its focus on referral patterns from primary to subspecialty providers. The databases allowed for inclusive definitions of obesity and the comorbidities, by combining patients identified by physician-generated ICD-9 code, patient-generated reason for visit, in many cases direct questioning of the provider regarding presence of a certain condition, and, for obesity and hypertension, mapping of documented values to age-specific percentiles.

The major limitation is the cross-sectional nature of the sample, with visit rather than patient as the observed unit, which does not allow for determination of longitudinal changes in a patient’s plan of care. As discussed above, the survey does not include questions assessing the motivation behind the decision whether or not to refer. Some of the definitions were not ideal, as in the use of a single blood pressure to map to standardized percentiles, given that the diagnosis of hypertension requires multiple measurements.9 There is no specific ICD-9 code for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, and no direct questioning available in the databases for this condition, making identification of patients with this comorbidity difficult. Due to low numbers of sampled visits for certain subgroups, weighted frequencies and percentages may be considered unreliable. Last, there are numerous complications of obesity, and some common ones, such as sleep apnea and musculoskeletal pain, were not included in the analysis.

In summary, we found that the majority of patients with obesity and obesity-related comorbidities are not referred out of primary care, with results suggesting that this may be due, at least in part, to lack of appropriate identification of these patients. Given that prior studies have shown that less than half of attending physicians use the recommended definitions of overweight and obesity, increased education and electronic decision support around obesity care should be implemented.24 Longitudinal studies will be needed to better characterize gaps in the process of identifying overweight and obese patients, screening for complications, and recognizing and acting on abnormal results.

sec.title: Coding Definitions
sec.p: A condition was considered to be present if at least one of the following survey responses was present.

list-item.p: V85.53 BMI, pediatric, 85th to <95th percentile for age
V85.54 BMI, pediatric, ≥95th percentile for age
Affirmative answer to survey question, “Regardless of the diagnosis . . . does the patient now have obesity?”
Measured body mass index ≥85th percentile for age and gender
V20.2 Routine infant or child health check
V70.0 Routine general medical examination at a health care facility
7100.0 Physical examination required for school or employment
2505.0 Hypertension with involvement of target organs
Affirmative answer to survey question,“Regardless of the diagnosis . . . does the patient now have hypertension?”
Measured systolic or diastolic blood pressure ≥95th percentile for age, gender, and height percentile9
790.29 Other abnormal glucose (includes abnormal glucose NOS, abnormal nonfasting glucose, hyperglycemia NOS, prediabetes NOS)
6100.0 For results of blood glucose tests
Affirmative answer to survey question, “Regardless of the diagnosis . . . does the patient now have diabetes?”
2215.0 Other endocrine, nutritional, metabolic and immunity diseases (includes hypercholesterolemia, hyperlipidemia)
6105.0 For results of cholesterol and triglyceride tests
Affirmative answer to survey question, “Regardless of the diagnosis . . . does the patient now have hyperlipidemia?”
571.9 Unspecified chronic liver disease without mention of alcohol
794.8 Nonspecific abnormal results of function studies, liver
2670.0 Diseases of the liver, gallbladder, and pancreas
Affirmative answer to survey question, “Regardless of the diagnosis . . . does the patient now have depression?”
